title: Kazimierz Konopka
text:
Kazimierz Konopka (1769-1805 or 1809) was a <a href="Polish%20Jacobins">Polish Jacobin</a>, secretary of <a href="Hugo%20Ko%C5%82%C5%82%C4%85taj">Hugo Kołłątaj</a>, officer in the <a href="Polish%20Legions%20%28Napoleonic%20period%29">Polish Legions</a>, aide-de-camp of <a href="Jan%20Henryk%20D%C4%85browski">Jan Henryk Dąbrowski</a>. He gained notoriety for his involvements in the unrest and <a href="hanging">hanging</a>s in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> during the <a href="Ko%C5%9Bciuszko%20Uprising">Kościuszko Uprising</a>.
Biography.
Konopka was born in 1769 to a <a href="%3Awikt%3Aburgher">burgher</a> family in <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a>. He studies law in <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a>, where he was a lawyer applicant in the F. Barss legal practice. Member of the <a href="Ko%C5%82%C5%82%C4%85taj%27s%20Forge">Kołłątaj's Forge</a> organization and one of the <a href="Polish%20Jacobins">Polish Jacobins</a>, and secretary to <a href="Hugo%20Ko%C5%82%C5%82%C4%85taj">Hugo Kołłątaj</a>; during Kołlataj's period as the <a href="Deputy%20Crown%20Chancellor">Deputy Crown Chancellor</a> (podkanclerz koronny) in 1791, Konopka held the position of the Secretary of the Lesser Seal (sekretarz pieczęci mniejszej).
He participated in the <a href="Ko%C5%9Bciuszko%20Uprising">Kościuszko Uprising</a>, joining the <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a>. During that period, around May and June 1794, he gained notoriety as one of the leaders of the demonstrations and riots in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>. In particular, he was involved in the "hanging of the traitors" incident around 28 June. In this incident, not supported by the insurrectionist government, out of several people hanged, including insurrection opponents such as chamberlain <a href="Karol%20Boscamp-Lasopolski">Karol Boscamp-Lasopolski</a>, prince <a href="Antoni%20Stanis%C5%82aw%20Czetwerty%C5%84ski-%C5%9Awiatope%C5%82k">Antoni Stanisław Czetwertyński-Światopełk</a> and bishop <a href="Ignacy%20Jakub%20Massalski">Ignacy Jakub Massalski</a>, the defense attorney and a prosecutor who attempted to stop the mob were also beaten and hanged; they included a friend of <a href="Tadeusz%20Ko%C5%9Bciuszko">Tadeusz Kościuszko</a>, advocate <a href="Micha%C5%82%20Wulfers">Michał Wulfers</a>.
For his involvement in the incident, Koponka was sentenced by the insurrectionist court to an <a href="exile">exile</a> (banicja).
Koponka left for <a href="France">France</a>, where he joined French cavalry, and fought in <a href="Corsica">Corsica</a>. In the aftermath of the final <a href="Third%20Partition%20of%20Poland">Third Partition of Poland</a>, after <a href="Polish%20Legions%20%28Napoleonic%20period%29">Polish Legions</a> were recreated under the French control in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, he became involved in the formation creation, reaching a rank of a <a href="Captain%20%28OF-2%29">captain</a> or <a href="major">major</a> (sources vary). He commanded a squadron, and later, a baon. In 1801 he was an aide-de-camp of <a href="Jan%20Henryk%20D%C4%85browski">Jan Henryk Dąbrowski</a>.
He died in 1805 in <a href="Bari">Bari</a> (Pachoński mentions a sudden <a href="heart%20attack">heart attack</a>) or in 1809 (according to Rusinowa).
Konopka is one of the figures immortalized in <a href="Jan%20Matejko">Jan Matejko</a>'s 1891 painting, "<a href="Constitution%20of%20May%203%2C%201791%20%28painting%29">Constitution of May 3, 1791</a>." He is shown near the center, with an outstretched hand, holding the <a href="czekan">czekan</a> (an ax- and hammer-like weapon) and with a French blue-white-red flower in his hat.
